intro: Elsota welwitschii, commonly known as the Welwitschii mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant native to southern Africa. It belongs to the family Viscaraceae and is characterized by its woody stems and evergreen leaves. The plant attaches itself to host trees, such as acacias, using a specialized structure called a haustellum to extract water and nutrients. Its flowers are small and white, typically appearing in clusters, and it produces small, fleshy berries that are dispersed by birds. Elsota welwitschii is notable for its ability to survive in arid environments and has adapted to thrive in the harsh conditions of its native habitat.
